characters: CUT BACK TO PRIYA IN OSLO -
THEY MAKE EYE CONTACT... SATOR STRIKES THE FELLOW WORKER
INTO HIMSELF AND NEIL, DRESSED AS BUSINESSMEN AS IN THEIR
RACING THROUGH THE STREETS, PAST THE IMPLODING/ EXPLODING
THE FLAMES CONTRACT, SPARING THE PROTAGONIST WHO LIES THE
BOUNCING VIOLENTLY, DUSTILY OFF EACH OTHER AND FLYING UP
METAL CAPSULE. A FELLOW WORKER SEES THE SAME THING...
UNDERNEATH. THE FELLOW WORKER LEANS IN, STUDYING THE GOLD
THEIR DOORS OR SHOOT OUT THROUGH THE BULLET-PROOF VEHICLE
MASSIVE MINING MACHINE, CARRYING A GIANT CROWBAR AND A GE
SLIDES HIM AT THE GAP BELOW THE RAIL -
JUST AS THE BLACK METAL SHAPE JUMPS OUT OF THE SAAB AND I
YOU CAN'T JIBE A BOAT LIKE THIS
TRIPWIRE WHICH BLOWS THE TUNNEL ENTRANCE DOWN BEHIND THEM
PAPERS, WHICH HAVE HIS NAME ON THEM, REVEALING GOLD BARS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As POLICE FLOOD THE PLAZA, the DRIVER turns to the PASSEN

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (in Ukrainian) - Wake up the Americans. - The Passenger turns to the back where four BLACK-CLAD YOU MEN SIT, WAITING. The nearest one seems to be SLEEPING...

dialogues.speaker: PASSENGER
dialogues.text: Hey - EYES CLOSED, the young man COCKS his weapon, chambering a round, POPS it out of the slide, CATCHES it, opens his ey this is THE PROTAGONIST... The Passenger nods, ‘okay’. The Driver looks down at a VARIETY OF UNIFORM PATCHES... SIRENS. The Americans shoulder WEAPONS, pull on HELMETS.. A UKRAINIAN SWAT VAN SCREECHES to a halt outside the thea The Passenger spots its markings - TOSSES the correspondi patches to the Americans, who slap them onto their should Ukrainian SWATs pour out of the SWAT van - The Americans JUMP out of the back of their van, SLIPPING UNNOTICED INTO THE STREAM OF SWATS pouring into the lobby

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SWATs mass at each entrance... the Protagonist watches GA CANISTERS brought in TO THE AIR-CONDITIONING SYSTEM. The SWATs pull on GAS MASKS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WELL-DRESSED MAN sitting next to a UNIFORMED OFFICIAL l down into the stalls - people SLUMP, UNCONSCIOUS, IN A WAVE...  He turns to the Official - who motions calm, draws a SIDEARM...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Terrorist wets a rag in a drinking fountain, ties it ar his nose and mouth. Others have WORKMAN’S RESPIRATORS AND FACE MASKS. They COCK THEIR WEAPONS, preparing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SWATS BREACH - POURING into the theatre - exchange GUNFIRE with the TERRORISTS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RUNNING. Fast but silent... FOLLOW the four Americans - they hit a junction - hand signals - they SPLIT two ways - FOLLOW two of them - one of them PEELS OFF up a staircase FOLLOW the last, the Protagonist - checking each box... INT. BOX, CONCERT HALL —- CONTINUOUS The Protagonist BURSTS in - takes out the Official beside Well-Dressed Man -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: We live in a twilight world... The Well-Dressed Man stares, shocked -—

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We live in a twilight world...

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: (focuses ) And there are no friends at dusk.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You’ve been made. This siege is a blind for them to vanish you.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: But I’ve established contact -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Bring you in or kill you - I have two minutes. Make up your mind. The Well-Dressed Man nods, climbs to his feet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where’s the package?

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: Coat check. He hands the Protagonist a numbered ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battle between SWATs and Terrorists rages... SWATS mo down the corridor, checking the boxes one by one... INT. BOX, CONCERT HALL —- CONTINUOUS The Protagonist SMASHES the glass - checks the drop to th stalls, pulls out a black rope, ties it to a column... As they DROP, Terrorist gunfire rings out - they LAND - hiding amongst the UNCONSCIOUS AUDIENCE. The Well-Dressed takes a seat, FEIGNS SLEEP - the Protagonist ROLLS under seats — BLAM! Terrorists near the stage open fire - SHOTS ring ou hitting two sleeping audience members, nearby - the Well- Dressed Man TWITCHES - the Protagonist holds his ankle - urging him to keep still - BLAM! A third sleeping audience member is shot - the Protagonist jumps up, DRAWING THE TERRORISTS’ fire away f the Well-Dressed Man - The Protagonist races towards two REAL UKRAINIAN SWATS wh cover him from the Terrorists - one of them goes down. The Protagonist takes cover beside the real UKRAINIAN SWA WHO IS PLANTING A BOMB UNDER THE SEATS... he gestures to dead SWAT’s pack... the Protagonist unzips the bag to fin BOMB, COUNTING DOWN IN SYNC WITH THE OTHER BOMB —

dialogues.speaker: UKRAINIAN SWAT
dialogues.text: (in Ukrainian, impatient) - What’re you doing? - The Ukrainian SWAT uses his gun to PROD the Velcro patch the Protagonist’s shoulder. It FALLS OFF...

dialogues.speaker: UKRAINIAN SWAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in Ukrainian) - Who are you? - The Protagonist is at a loss... BAM! The Ukrainian SWAT i taken out by another ‘SWAT’ -  ‘SWAT’ No friends at dusk, huh?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You'll do. The Protagonist GRABS the bombs, points at the Well-Dress Man -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the ‘SWAT’) Get him to the rally point. The ‘SWAT’ leads the Well-Dressed Man down a fire exit - INT. LOBBY, CONCERT HALL —- CONTINUOUS The Protagonist RACES across the lobby, gunfire RINGING O LEAPS over the counter into the COAT-CHECK AREA... Landing on the floor next to an unconscious coat-check gi He spots another bomb - ‘4:23’, ‘4:22’... the Protagonist checks the number on the coat-check ticket and efficientl moves across numbered racks until he finds a SPORTS BAG. He unzips it to find a BLACK METALLIC OBJECT the size of softball. He stuffs it into his pack and SCRAMBLES over the counter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the Protagonist RUNS, checking numbers on doors... he S at a door, THROWS it open, JUMPS in low -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE ‘SWATS’, guns trained, and the Well-Dressed Man. Th Protagonist throws a bomb to SWAT 2, then shows the OBJEC the Well-Dressed Man -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’ve never seen encapsulation like this.

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: We don’t know how old it is. It’s the real deal.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Did you have an out?

dialogues.speaker: WELL-DRESSED MAN
dialogues.text: Service tunnels to sewers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swap clothes. The ‘SWAT’ and the Well-Dressed Man start changing. The Protagonist hands SWAT 3 the object -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Take this, take him, take his exit. I don’t trust ours any more. (to SWAT 2) Can you defuse it?

dialogues.speaker: SWAT 2
dialogues.text: (shakes head) Centrally synchronized. Are there more? The Protagonist nods, STUFFS the bomb in his pack -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Covering their tracks.

dialogues.speaker: SWAT 2
dialogues.text: Taking out the audience?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Just the cheap seats.

dialogues.speaker: SWAT 3
dialogues.text: Not our mission -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Mine, now. The newly dressed ‘TARGET’ steps up -— ‘TARGET’ I’m with you - the Ukrainians are expecting a passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and the ‘Target’ race through the SLEEPIN AUDIENCE COLLECTING BOMBS - the TIMERS tick down - ‘1:58’ 1:57". Crouched at a bomb, the Protagonist notices a BULLET HOLE the side of the chair - a TINY WHIFF OF SMOKE GATHERING.. CLICK - a gun is to his head - he spins around to see a SWAT. 0:34’, ‘0:33’... The ‘Target’ has his own gun on th SWAT - A STAND-OFF - all around them, UNCONSCIOUS CIVILIANS...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Walk away - you don’t need to kill these people.  6. The Protagonist turns back to the bomb... ‘0:32’, ‘0:31’. the bullet hole the PUFF OF SMOKE THICKENS... the Protagonist, confused, REACHES towards it... the SWAT COC his weapon... BLAM! With EXPLOSIVE FORCE THE BULLET HOLE DISAPPEARS - A NICK HAS APPEARED IN THE PROTAGONIST’S UNIFORM - he SPINS the SWAT is SHOT THROUGH THE CHEST AND DROPS... revealing FIGURE, also in a gas mask and tactical gear... The Figure TURNS - the Protagonist sees, on the Figure’s pack, a small TALISMAN - a COIN with a hole tied to a zip ORANGE AND YELLOW THREAD - the Protagonist turns back to the bomb - ‘TARGET’ That wasn’t one of us.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’ll take the help. The Protagonist GRABS the last bomb: ‘0:03’... he looks u the boxes, where REAL SWATS EVACUATE THE HIGH OFFICIALS.. THE PROTAGONIST LOBS THE BOMBS UP INTO THE BOXES...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and ‘Target’ emerge - an EXPLOSION above

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INNOCENT CIVILIANS STIR under the EXPLOSION IN THE BOXES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van PULLS UP - rear door open - they JUMP INSIDE - INT. VAN —- MOMENTS LATER The Protagonist pulls off his mask. BREATHING. The Passen turns - grabs the ‘Target’s face, SOMETHING WRONG... the Protagonist turns to the Driver - WHO HAS A GUN POINTED A HIM ...

dialogues.speaker: BLACK SCREEN
dialogues.text: SCREAMING. The Protagonist’s screaming. Close on his eyes FLICKERING, SWEATING, PLEADING, DEFIANT... and we are -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist, tied to a chair, in a windswept rail yar In front of him, the ‘Target’, also tied to a chair, back us. The Driver steps back, SWEATING. BLOODY PLIERS in han

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (breathless) A man can be trained to hold out for about eighteen hours. The Driver gestures at a CLOCK on a table -

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So your colleagues will clear by 7. The Driver PUSHES the ‘Target’s chair over. The ‘Target’ lands hard on his side on the gravel. Groaning.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He didn’t last eighteen minutes. The Driver pulls out a KNIFE. Leans in to the Protagonist

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But he didn’t have anything to hide. You were smuggling a nobody. The knife moves towards the Protagonist’s throat...

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Risky. ...then to his collar - which he CUTS -

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Or were you counting on this? ..-pulling out a SILVER CAPSULE. The Protagonist stares.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Death, CIA issue. The Driver TOSSES the pill, WAVES the pliers at the clock

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Spare yourself once they’re clear. The Protagonist looks at the clock - ‘5:38’. A FREIGHT TR RUMBLES PAST, CLOSE... As we close in on the clock, THE PROTAGONIST’S SCREAMS ARE DROWNED OUT BY THE FREIGHT TRAI The Driver steps back. The Protagonist breathes heavy, bl dribbling... the Driver follows his gaze to the clock - 6:53’ - then checks his watch. Frowns theatrically, picks the clock, SHAKES it -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running fast... The Driver SETS THE HANDS BACK ONE HOUR. The Protagonist watches, DESPAIRING... as the Driver puts the clock back the table, the Protagonist notices the ‘Target’s FINGERS WIGGLING... in them is a SILVER PILL... Freight trains rumble past in opposite directions, sound BUILDING... The Driver approaches, bloody pliers in hand

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: We were alone.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: I didn’t ask. Which means we're finally getting somewhere. The Protagonist HURLS himself onto the ‘Target’s hands - SMASHING - gets the PILL into his mouth - BITES DOWN - DEAFENING TRAIN NOISE... Arms GRAB at him - HANDS PRY his jaw as he SEIZES, MOUTH FOAMING... the Protagonist’s EYES GLAZE and we -

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Black screen. Supertitle:

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: on face The Protagonist opens his eyes. A man stands beside his b SWAYING gently. This is FAY.

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: Welcome to the afterlife. The Protagonist lifts his head and we are -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist sees the STEELY OCEAN SWELL...

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: You've been in a medically induced coma while we got you out of Ukraine and rebuilt your mouth.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The pills are fake?

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: We swapped yours for a sedative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: A test. The Protagonist runs a finger around his mouth. REALIZING

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Test? They pulled my teeth out. Fay lets that dissipate. The Protagonist closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Did the team get clear?

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: No. Private Russians, we think.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Somebody talked.

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: Not you. You chose to die instead of giving up your colleagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist stands in the wind, contemplating the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: FAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We all believe we’d run into the burning building, but until we feel that heat... we can never know. You do.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I resign.

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: You don’t work for us - you’re dead. The Protagonist turns to Fay, confused.

dialogues.speaker: FAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your duty transcends national interests. This is about survival.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Whose?

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: Everyone's. There’s a cold war. Cold as ice. To even know its true nature is to lose. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: FAY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is knowledge divided - all I have for you is a gesture -— (interlaces his fingers) - in combination with a word - ‘tenet’. Use it carefully, it’ll open the right doors, but some of the wrong ones, too.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: That’s all they’ve told you?

dialogues.speaker: FAY
dialogues.text: The test you passed? (beat) Not everybody does. Fay breaks eye contact with the Protagonist. The boat continues to nose into the swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist is driven away from the boat on a launch, towards the GIANT WHITE TURBINES of the ocean wind farm. The launch SLIPS amongst them, seeking the ladder of a particular one... The Protagonist climbs the ladder to a door. He tries it it’s open. He turns to see the launch move off into the gathering dark. The Protagonist ENTERS the wind turbine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bare space, the Protagonist finds a SPORTS BAG, a a pallet of WATER and PROTEIN BARS. He opens the sports b to find passports, cash, credit cards and a HI-VIZ VEST. Under the vest is a small black cylinder. He unscrews the to find three SILVER SUICIDE PILLS. The Protagonist shake his head as he tosses them back into the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist EATS, DRINKS and EXERCISES by CLIMBING th endless interior ladder of the turbine. The stash of food water SHRINKS... The Protagonist does PULL-UPS at the very top of the ladd FEET DANGLING over the VERTIGINOUS DROP...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist is woken by a repeated AIR HORN. He pulls himself off the cot, opens the door to find -  11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large CATAMARAN nosed up to the windmill, ladder in pla MAINTENANCE CREW in HI-VIZ VESTS moving on and off the turbine. Other boats service other turbines. The Protagon pulls on his VEST and CLIMBS down onto the catamaran.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist disembarks with the rest of the wind-farm crew. As they file past a car the driver, also in hi-viz, steps out into line, leaving the door open, engine runnin The Protagonist gets in. The GPS is already set...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bland suburban office park. The Protagonist gets out of car, wearing his hi-viz and carrying a clipboard. Heads inside, passing numerous STAFF coming out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist moves through the lobby unimpeded. Checki the tenant listings he sees - ‘WINDFARM TRANSITIONS - B-2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist walks up to B-2.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: With a hi-viz vest and a clipboard, you can get almost anywhere. Almost. The Protagonist turns to find a brusque young woman. This BARBARA. He joins his hands, interlacing the fingers...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: A pretty obscure tenet. Using a key card, she ushers him through a door into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara hands the Protagonist a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No small talk, nothing that might reveal who we are, or what we do.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I thought I was here to find out what we do.  12.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You’re not here for ‘what’, you’re here for ‘how’. ‘What’ is your department. And not my business.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Well, to do what I do, I need some idea of the threat we face. Barbara considers the Protagonist. Sips her tea.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: As I understand it, we’re trying to prevent World War Three.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Nuclear holocaust?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No. Something worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barbara hands the Protagonist a semi-automatic. He reflexively checks the chamber and magazine - EMPTY.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Aim it and pull the trigger. The Protagonist SHRUGS, lifts the empty pistol, sights a target 25m away with several holes in it... He squeezes the trigger - BAM! - a shot. He is CONFUSED..

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Check the magazine. The Protagonist checks the clip - THERE IS A ROUND IN IT.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: How? Barbara pulls on PROTECTIVE GLOVES and removes the round the clip, placing it next to an identical one on a table.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: One of these bullets is, like us, travelling forwards through time. The other one’s going backwards. Can you tell which is which? The Protagonist shakes his head. Barbara reaches forward

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How about now? -  13. One of the rounds FLIES UP INTO HER HAND, FALLING IN REVE The Protagonist is taken aback. Barbara holds the round towards him so he can inspect it -

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It's inverted - its entropy runs backwards. So, to our eyes, its movement is reversed. We think it’s a type of inverse radiation, triggered by nuclear fission.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You didn’t make it?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: We don’t know how. Yet.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: So where’d it come from?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Someone’s manufacturing them in the future. They’re streaming back at us. Barbara places the round on the table, in front of a CAME

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Try it. He puts on a glove - moves his hand over it, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have to have dropped it. The Protagonist reaches out again - it LEAPS UP INTO HIS HAND.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: How can it move before I touch it? She cues up the recording of what he just did -

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: From your point of view you caught it, but from the bullet’s point of view... She plays it BACKWARDS -—

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-you dropped it. ON THE SCREEN: the round FALLS from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: But cause has to come before effect.  14.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: No. That’s just how we see time. She PULLS the round towards herself using one finger - th round follows her finger as if MAGNETIZED...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: What about free will?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: That bullet wouldn't have moved if you hadn’t put your hand there. Either way we run the tape, you made it happen. She LAUNCHES it up into her other hand -

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t try to understand it. Feel it. Barbara PLAYS with the round in increasingly IMPROBABLE, BEAUTIFUL MOVEMENTS... The round SHOOTS AWAY FROM HER - t Protagonist CATCHES IT...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Instinct. Got it. Barbara smiles, swaps him the round for the pistol. She t places a TRAY COVERED IN SHELL CASINGS beside him. The Protagonist aims at the target - a shell casing LEAPS into the gun - he FIRES, and a bullet hole near the bulls VANISHES —-

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why does it feel so strange?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: You’re not shooting the bullet, you’re catching it.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Whoa. The Protagonist examines the target - no bullet holes.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve seen this type of ammunition before.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: In the field?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I was almost hit.  15.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Then you are exceedingly lucky... The Protagonist turns to her...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: An inverted bullet passing through your body would be devastating. The inverse radiation would spread through your body. Like polonium poisoning. Not pretty. The Protagonist examines the rounds...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: These look like today’s.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: They may have been made today, then inverted years from now.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Where did you get them?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: They came with the wall. I was assigned it, like all the material I’m studying here.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Do you have an analysis of the metals?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Sure. Why?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The mixture of alloys can tell me where they might have been made. Look, I know you said that ‘what’ is my business -

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: Let’s not go off-topic.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m not seeing Armageddon here. Barbara takes the round from him, and beckons him to foll

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between tall sets of DRAWERS...  16.

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: A bullet may not seem like much, but it’s a simple machine - lead bullet, brass casing, gunpowder. If they can invert this - I see no reason they couldn’t invert pretty much anything. Even a nuclear weapon can only affect our future. An inverted weapon might be able to affect our past as well. Barbara stops at a drawer. Gestures around herself -

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now that we know what to look for, we're finding more and more inverted material... She opens a drawer, revealing a VARIETY OF RUSTED BITS AN PIECES - SCREWS, CRACKED LENSES, METAL RODS, BUTTONS...

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...remnants of complex objects. The Protagonist reaches out and lets a RUSTED BUCKLE leap into his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: So what do you think we’re seeing?

dialogues.speaker: BARBARA
dialogues.text: The detritus of a coming war. The Protagonist looks around at the MULTITUDE of DRAWERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist walks out of an electronics store, openin new phone, and slips into the throng. He dials -

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Yup?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: We live in a twilight world.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) No friends at dusk. I was told you'd left the building.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Even the dead need allies.  17.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Specifically?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: An assist in Mumbai. To get to Sanjay Singh.

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) Singh? He never leaves his house, and his house... well, it’s -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Yes, it is - I’m looking right at it. Above the bustling street, a HIGH-RISE HOUSE, at least tw storeys tall, with two large balconies, towers over...

dialogues.speaker: MALE VOICE
dialogues.text: (over phone) I’1l see who’s on deck. Bombay Yacht Club, two hours. As the Protagonist hangs up, he spots a figure, on the to balcony. A WOMAN IN A SARI, standing high above the city.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist enters the quiet ex-colonial establishmen Takes a seat. A BUSINESSMAN sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: BUSINESSMAN
dialogues.text: It seems you need an introduction to a prominent Mumbai local on short notice. I’m Neil. Neil offers his hand. The Protagonist takes it -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I need an audience with Sanjay Singh.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Not possible.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Ten minutes, tops.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Time isn’t the problem. Getting out alive’s the problem. (thinks) Would you take a child hostage? The Protagonist shakes his head.  18.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A woman?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: If I had to. I’m not looking to make much noise here. Neil keeps thinking. Signals a waiter -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Vodka tonic. (gestures at the Protagonist) Diet Coke. The Protagonist stares at Neil. Neil looks up, confused.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What? You never drink on the job.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You're well informed.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: It pays to be in our profession.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Well, I prefer club soda.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (grins) No, you don’t. Neil raps his knuckles on the table, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How’s your parachuting?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Broke an ankle in basic training. Singh’s house isn’t tall enough to parachute off of.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (thinks ) But it’s bungee-jumpable.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I don’t think ‘bungee-jumpable’ is a word.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: It may not be a word, but it may be your only way out of that place. (a thought occurs) Or into it, for that matter.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARMED GUARDS patrol the balconies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside one of the magnificent rooms, a middle-aged Indian mixes drinks. This is SANJAY SINGH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil and the Protagonist race across the roof carrying a sports bag. Neil pulls out a WINCH, the Protagonist pulls a large CATAPULT, loops it around two pipes, glancing dow into the WALLED YARD at the foot of the high-rise house. Neil BOLTS the winch to the roof, the Protagonist sights upper balcony of the high-rise house, FIRES a ball with a line up and over the balcony railing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and Neil lie next to each other as the WI RUNS, TENSIONING THEIR ELASTIC LINES... they LAUNCH themselves, FLYING UP to land against the side of the building - They RUN SILENTLY UP THE BUILDING, onto the UPPER TERRACE SHOOTING TWO GUARDS with silenced pistols...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanjay Singh hands a drink to the Woman in the sari. They move out onto the balcony -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist surprises Sanjay, holds him at gunpoint -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: (to the Woman) Stay back. (to Sanjay) I was almost taken out by a very unusual type of ammunition in Ukraine. I want to know who supplied it.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: My name’s Sanjay. And you are? (silence) No chit-chat?  20. The Woman pushes a RED BUTTON on the wall -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: There’s no one at the other end. No one who’s going to help you, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An alarm buzzes, the Security Guards are frozen, Neil has gun on them, a finger to his lips...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sanjay tries to turn to see the Protagonist -

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: Why would I know who supplied it? The Protagonist pushes his head back around with the gun

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The combination of metals is unique to India. If it’s from India, it’s from you.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: A fair assumption -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Deduction.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: Deduction, then. Look, my friend, guns are never conducive to a productive negotiation.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m not the man they send to negotiate... He COCKS his weapon - puts the gun to Sanjay’s head -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I am the man people talk to.

dialogues.speaker: SANJAY
dialogues.text: (charm curdles) I can’t. I can’t tell you.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You're an arms dealer, friend - this may be the easiest trigger I’ve ever had to pull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To say anything about a client would violate the tenets he lives by... 21. The Protagonist GLANCES at the Woman... whose fingers are casually INTERTWINED. The Protagonist brings his free han to hold the gun in both hands, fingers INTERLACED...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: If tenets are important to you, then you can tell me. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Not while you have a gun to my husband's head. The Protagonist releases him.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sanjay, make us a drink. INT. TERRACE OVERLOOKING MUMBAI, SANJAY’S HOUSE - LATER Overlooking the extraordinary bustle of the city. Sanjay left. His wife hands the Protagonist his drink -

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: I’m Priya Singh.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: This is your operation?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: A masculine front in a man’s world has its uses. The dealer you're looking for is Andrei Sator.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The Russian oligarch?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: You know him?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Not personally. Made his billions in gas, moved to London and married an English girl. Said to be on the outs with Moscow.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Very good. Except the ‘gas’ he made his billions from was actually plutonium, and he’s said to be on the outs so he can feed British Intelligence whatever the Russians want them to think they know.  22.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: None of which explains how or why you sold him inverted munitions.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: When I sold him the rounds, they were perfectly ordinary.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: So how did he get them inverted?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We believe he’s functioning as some kind of broker between our time and the future.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: He can communicate with the future?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We all do. Credit cards, email, text - anything that goes into the record speaks directly to the future. The question is - can the future speak back? And, if so, what are they saying?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And I’m supposed to find out?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: To get anywhere near Sator would take a fresh-faced protagonist... She reaches up to touch his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fresh as a daisy. Get close, find out what he’s receiving and how.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Is it safe to involve British Intelligence?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: I have a contact who’s out of Sator’s reach.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: One of us?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: No, he thinks we’re chasing plutonium. SIRENS. BANGS! Priya looks over to see POLICE CARS arrivi far below, in the WALLED YARD at the foot of her house...  23.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'd better get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Can’t you explain things?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: You have to start looking at the world in a new way - this conflict runs backwards and forwards simultaneously. Your name on a police report reveals your identity to the future - they pass it back to Sator -—

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: My cover’s blown before I get near him.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: You got in - you must've had a plan for getting out. The Protagonist pulls a CLIP and cord from his harness -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Not one I loved. Priya watches him clip onto the balcony rail. Neil FLIES PAST, dropping from the balcony above. The Protagonist JUMPS, SLOWING as he DROPS BEHIND THE WAL OUT OF REACH OF THE POLICE, into a MARKET STREET and RELE his harness - disappearing into the crowd...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist walks down the busy Mall, and up the step

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist enters, is approached by a STEWARD.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: Can I help you, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m Mr Crosby’s lunch.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: I presume you mean Sir Michael Crosby’s lunch?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Presume away.  24.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: If you'll follow me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist is shown to a table where a distinguished middle-aged man is already eating. CROSBY.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Started without you, hope you don’t mind.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’1l catch up. (to the Steward) Same for me.

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: I‘'ll send the waiter.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: No, just pass on the order. Crosby smiles at the Protagonist’s handling of the Stewar

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: I gather you’ve an interest ina certain Russian national.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Anglo-Russian. So I’1ll have to watch my step.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Indeed. He’s tapped into the intelligence services - I’ve warned them he’s feeding them rubbish, but they don’t seem to care.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Tell me about him.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: I assume you’re familiar with the Soviet-era secret cities?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Closed cities, not shown on maps, built up around sensitive industries. Most of them have been opened up and renamed as regular towns.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Not the one Sator grew up in. Stalsk-12. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: In the seventies our people estimated its population at almost 200,000. Unacknowledged to this day. Thought to be abandoned.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Abandoned?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Some kind of accident. After which we think it became a site for underground tests. Just two weeks ago, same day as the Kiev Opera siege, our satellites detected a detonation in north-west Siberia, about where we think Stalsk-12 was.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Nuclear?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Big enough to be noticed. Sator emerged from this blank spot on the map with an ambition that eventually led him here, to buy his way into the British establishment.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Through his wife?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Katherine Barton, eldest niece of Sir Frederick Barton. She works at Shipley’s, met Sator at an auction.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: He’s into art?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Like a lot of wealthy criminals, he thinks if he covers his walls with tasteful, expensive things it’ll distract from the bloodshed. Judging by the lovely girl he married, there might be something in it.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Happy marriage?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: No. Practically estranged.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: How do I get to Sator?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Through her, of course.  26.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You may have an inflated idea of my powers of seduction.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Hardly. We have an ace in the hole... Crosby slides a SHOPPING BAG over to the Protagonist’s fe The Protagonist looks inside: a small FRAMED DRAWING.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You’re carrying a Goya in a Harrods bag?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: It's a fake, by a Spaniard named Arepo. One of two we confiscated from an embezzler in Bern. We hung on to this one for a rainy day - I felt the first drops when India called.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: What happened to the other one?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: A Rubens. It turned up at Shipley’s, where it was authenticated by Katherine Barton before going under the hammer. And who do you suppose bought it?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Her husband? Does she know it’s a forgery?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Hard to say. Rumour had it that she and Arepo were close. Crosby looks the Protagonist over -

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, no offence, but this is a world where someone claiming to be a billionaire gets asked if they’re just a dollar billionaire.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Brooks Brothers won’t cut it.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m assuming I have a budget.  27.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: (tosses him a credit card) Save the world, then we’ll balance the books. Can I recommend a tailor?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I‘1l manage. You British don’t have a monopoly on snobbery, you know.

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: Not a monopoly. More of a controlling interest. The Protagonist rises, taking the credit card and the bag

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Thanks for this. By the way, is she a Kate or a Kathy?

dialogues.speaker: CROSBY
dialogues.text: A Kat, I believe. The waiter arrives, bearing food, supervised by the Stewa

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Could you box that for me?

dialogues.speaker: STEWARD
dialogues.text: Certainly not. The Protagonist smiles at Crosby, who nods goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Sir Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mothers stand at the railings waiting for their kids. One them, a smart YOUNG WOMAN, stands a little apart from the group. SCHOOLKIDS pile out of the school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist watches from across the road as the Young Woman SPOTS her son. She offers him her hand, but he reac up to take his NANNY’S. She moves her hand to pick someth off his jumper before he is put into the back of a BLACK RANGE ROVER with tinted windows. The Protagonist watches the Young Woman wave at the depar car carrying her child. Utterly alone.  28. EXT. SHIPLEY’S, LONDON - DAY A BENTLEY pulls up - a DOORMAN opens the rear door, the Protagonist emerges, IMMACULATELY TAILORED, holding a beautiful leather briefcase. INT. SHIPLEY’S - CONTINUOUS The Protagonist is approached by a REPRESENTATIVE -

dialogues.speaker: REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: How can I help, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I have an appraisal with Ms Barton.

dialogues.speaker: REPRESENTATIVE
dialogues.text: (to receptionist) Tell Kat her client is in the Fallow Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist admires the paintings on the walls. The d opens and the Young Woman from the school gates comes in, dressed for business. This is KAT BARTON. She looks bemus but gives him a genuine and friendly smile -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I wasn’t notified of any appointments, Mr...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Goya?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Mr Goya? The Protagonist opens his briefcase...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: No, I’m told you’re the person to see about... Offers the drawing to her...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ..-Goya. She takes it, suddenly interested...

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Wow. It’s extraordinary. She lays the drawing on the table and grabs a loupe -  She The She Kat 29.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: What's it worth?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Let’s not get ahead of ourselves. There’s a lot of work before any kind of valuation - provenance, microscopic examination, X-rays... is bent over the table, peering through the loupe. Protagonist studies her reaction as he -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: But what does your heart tell you? steps back. Something about the drawing BOTHERS her...

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, where did you say you acquired this drawing?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Tomas Arepo. rises and turns to face the Protagonist. Cold.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: What I want is complicated.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Do you work for my husband?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’ve never met your husband. That’s the reason I’m here. Is there somewhere we can talk?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: In London? Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and Kat sit at a corner table.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I bought my Goya for cents on the dollar from an irate Swiss banker. Traced it to Arepo, and realized I'd scored a bargain when he told me who'd paid top dollar for another one of his pictures. Your husband.  30.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Where’s the bargain? Your drawing’s an obvious fake.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: My drawing’s a very good fake - you know that better than anyone. The information’s the bargain.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: The information that I helped defraud my own husband?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: He and I are in related businesses, but he’s a hard man to meet. If you and I were to make an arrangement -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Arrangement? You mean blackmail. Don’t be afraid of the word - my husband isn’t. And I’m sorry to tell you he got there first.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: He knows? And he’s never done anything about it?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Why would he?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: He paid nine million dollars -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Which would barely cover the holiday he just forced us on.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Where’d you go - Mars?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Viet Nam. On our yacht. His yacht. Kat looks the Protagonist up and down...

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You’ve got the suit. The shoes, the watch. But I think you’re a little out of your depth.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: (sharp) People who've amassed fortunes like your husband’s aren’t generally okay with being cheated out of any of it.  31. Kat sips her wine. Wanting to talk. Knowing she shouldn't

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: The drawing is his hold over me. He threatened me with the police, prison, the works. He controls me, my contact with my son, everything. Leaving him would never have been easy, now it’s impossible. My life, now... You can’t fight. Just beg. Or worse. In Viet Nam I tried to love him again. If there were still love, he might give me my son. We sat on that bloody boat and watched the sunsets, imitating an earlier time. He seemed happy, so I asked. And he made me an offer. To let me go if I agreed to never see my son again. I expressed myself - INSERT CUT: a CRYSTAL BOWL of RASPBERRIES SMASHES onto th polished wood of a yacht’s deck -

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then took Max ashore. He called us, contrite. But when we came back... INSERT CUT: Kat and Max on a launch - Kat follows Max’s g to see a FEMALE FIGURE SLIDE into the water...

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I glimpsed some other woman diving off the boat. And he’d vanished. I’ve never felt such envy.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You don’t seem the jealous type.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Of her. You know how I dream of just diving off that boat? Of freedom?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: But you share a son.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: And that’s my life.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Did you know the drawing was a fake?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: The authentication took months - Arepo and I became close, maybe too close. Maybe my judgement was clouded. I failed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But Andrei can’t conceive of failure, only betrayal. I didn’t betray my husband. In retrospect, maybe I missed my chance.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And he let Arepo walk free?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: If you’d actually met Arepo, as you claimed, you’d understand that he no longer walks anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: We spoke on the phone -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: He can’t do that, either. The Protagonist considers this.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Where’s the drawing?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Get me the introduction, I'll take the drawing out of the equation. No picture, no prosecution. No hold over you. Kat looks at the Protagonist. Not daring to hope.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I might just be your second chance

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (snaps ) I don’t need redemption.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: At betrayal. A LARGE, WELL-DRESSED THUG sits down at the table. He tak green bean from the Protagonist’s plate and chews it vacantly. This is VOLKOV. The Protagonist looks at Kat -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Friend of your husband? (she nods) You knew this would happen?  33.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: They won’t kill you. Andrei dislikes tangling with local law enforcement on that level.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You must really not have liked the look of me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: (rising) The look of you is fine. It’s better to get to the nasty part before I care one way or the other. He takes her hand, pulls her forward to kiss her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: (whispers) There’s a number in your left coat pocket. Don’t call from home. A Thug puts a MEATY HAND on the Protagonist’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You won't be taking my call.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I might surprise you. She leaves, BREEZING out through the kitchen... at Volkov nod, two Thugs escort the Protagonist from his chair, hea towards the kitchen - a WAITER moves to object - Volkov, eating the Protagonist’s leftovers, pulls the Waiter up short, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat exits the restaurant, DISTRAUGHT, walking past a wait THUG, then sliding into the back seat of a MERCEDES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver is a GAUNT RUSSIAN.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Please, let’s go. The Gaunt Russian does not react, but watches through the rear-view mirror as a THUG enters the kitchen -

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can we get going?  34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist enters the kitchen, followed by the two thugs. CHEFS and BUSBOYS retreat as the other thug approaches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat turns from the window -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Please!

dialogues.speaker: GAUNT RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: He wants you to see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist JACKKNIFES HIS LOWER LEG UP into the crot of the thug behind him - SPINS him into the Thug next to - POTS and Pans flying -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Volkov wipes sauce with bread, enjoying noises from the kitchen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Third Thug SWINGS - the Protagonist DODGES, takes the blow on the shoulder - SLAMS his head into the Third Thug neck, leaving him GASPING - the Protagonist GRABS the Thi Thug, RACING for the WINDOW...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat FLINCHES as, with a CRASH of plates, a body TUMBLES d the stairs...

dialogues.speaker: GAUNT RUSSIAN
dialogues.text: And he gets what he wants. Then she sees something else... the Protagonist exits.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Not always, apparently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist brushes himself clean, SPOTS the Mercedes starts moving towards it -  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gaunt Russian SCRAMBLES to get the car moving. Kat lo back at the Protagonist as the car ROARS away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kat is crouched, talking to her son, MAX. The Nanny hover

dialogues.speaker: MAX
dialogues.text: Anna says we’re going to Pompeii and see lava.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: We'll go together. I’1l be there, too. Max looks up at the Nanny. Kat hugs him, tight. The Nanny TAPS Kat on the shoulder. Kat smiles at her son, tears in eyes, as the car pulls away. She pulls out her phone, dials... hears a RINGTONE behind her - The Protagonist is there.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I said I'd surprise you. He’s a cute kid.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Max. He’s everything.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Where’s the drawing?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Oslo. At the airport.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The airport? INSERT CUT: a Rotas car drives across an airport apron, a down a ramp...

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Do you know what a freeport is?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: A storage facility for art that’s been acquired -— ...into a SLEEK facility - the OSLO FREEPORT - as a STAFF MEMBER stands ready to greet a new CLIENT...  36.

dialogues.speaker: KAT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But not yet taxed. We started a network - Rotas, his construction company, built them, I brought in clients. The facilities are tax havens... The client is NEIL... he takes in the security arrangements...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The clients can view their investments -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist is standing on the roof of the Oslo Opera House, briefing Neil...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - without importing them, so they avoid paying tax.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Sort of a transit lounge for art? We go back to Kat, on the street, briefing the Protagonis

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Art, antiques, anything of value, really.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Anything legal... Then back to the Protagonist briefing Neil...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: But it’s not unlike the Swiss banking system. Opaque. Back to Kat -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Rotas has assets in the Oslo Freeport. I’m guessing it’s there.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Guessing? Back to Oslo -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Guessing?  37. Back to Kat -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: We make trips there four or five times a year.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: To view art?

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: And whatever he does - it turns out art is of no importance to Andrei.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: But the freeports are. Kat nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A STAFF MEMBER brings Neil into a LUXURIOUS GALLERY -

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Some freeports are just warehouses - here, you can actually enjoy your possessions... Then through doors into an ANGLED INNER CORRIDOR...

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The structure of the vaults is based on The Pentagon - each vault a separate structure within the others. Damage to one structure won’t compromise the others. They arrive at a door in the corridor. The Staff Member u his thumb to unlock a door -

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Clients have biometric access straight in off the tarmac.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: From the terminal?

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: (confused) From their private planes.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Of course. Neil checks the locks as the Staff Member opens the door  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A VAST SHIPPING AREA filled with SHIPPING CONTAINERS -

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Our logistics department ships to and from other freeports without customs inspection... Neil notices ROTAS containers marked for delivery to TALL

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’re you hoping to find?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You really want to know?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I’m not sure.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Bring some lead-lined gloves.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Jesus. Nuclear?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: When you’re on the tour -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil is shown back into one of the vaults...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pay attention to the fire precautions.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Documents are vulnerable to -

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Fire. Absolutely -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I was going to say, water damage from sprinkler systems.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: We don’t use sprinklers. (points to vents) The facility is flooded with halide gas, displacing all the air within seconds.  39.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Can you show me?

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: If I did, we'd suffocate.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What about the staff in here?

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Halide only fills the vaults - they just have to get into the corridor. There’s a ten-second warning.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You only give them ten seconds?

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Our clients use us because we have no priorities above their property.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Blimey.

dialogues.speaker: STAFF MEMBER
dialogues.text: Well, sir, you asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and Neil walk through the terminal.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Vault doors are fireproof, hydraulic closers, simple key and electronic triggers. Surprisingly easy, once there’s a lockdown.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Why a lockdown?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Power switches to fail-safe, sealing outer doors, but inner doors revert to factory settings and pickable locks. Child’s play, really.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Child’s play? They’re inside airport security. They have to worry about climate control, not armed raids.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So how do we get fire power through the perimeter to trigger a lockdown?  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and Neil look across the tarmac to the freeport structure.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Back wall of the freeport... The Protagonist notices Neil start to smile...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You’ve got something?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You’re not going to like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist looks at Neil in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You want to crash a plane?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Not from the air, don’t be so dramatic. I want to run a jet off the taxiway, breach the rear wall, start a fire.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: How big a plane?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Well, that part is a little dramatic. They approach a MAN sitting on a harbour-front bench.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Mahir. His team will work the plane.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: There can’t be passengers -

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: Norskfreight. They use the hangar on the west side of the freeport.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You want to crash a transport plane? What about the crew?

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: We'll pop the slides, chuck ‘em off  4l.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: On the move?

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: What’s the problem? They’1l be fine.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: It seems... bold.

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: (smiles) ‘Bold’ I’m fine with - I thought you were going to say nuts.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And if you get caught?

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: We won’t.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: If you do?

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: Everyone assumes terrorism, but no one’s died. Swift extradition, then lost in the system. It’1ll barely make the news.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: That may depend on the size of your explosion.

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: Actually, the gold bars might get some play.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Gold bars?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Norskfreight ships treasury gold once a month.

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: We blow the back, drop the gold out on the runway.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: No one’s going to be looking at your building, I guarantee you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil takes LUNGFULS of air, hyperventilating - Mahir star stopwatch. The Protagonist studies some plans...  42.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: The space at the centre of the pentagon’s too big... there’s something there, not marked. Neil runs out of air. Mahir checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: A vault within a vault?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: Eighty-five seconds.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Ample.

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: Won’t you be running? (turns to the Protagonist) Start packing. The Protagonist starts BREATHING HARD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and Neil, carrying BRIEFCASES, head insid

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two WORKERS (Mahir and his associate, ROHAN) back up a ME TRUCK to a TRANSPORT PLANE. They LIFT the cargo until it level with the front side door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist follows Neil through security. Their briefcases are examined, finding FRAMED DOCUMENTS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahir and Rohan carry crew meals through the door and int the galley, where they stack them into the catering units supervised by a GUARD...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Staff Member brings Neil an espresso. The Protagonist subtly checks his watch...  43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahir points past the Guard -

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR
dialogues.text: You gonna eat that? The Guard turns - Mahir GRABS him from behind, Rohan stuf COTTON PAD over the Guard’s face, rendering him unconscio They ROLL him into the catering-truck lift... Mahir pops and signals ANOTHER GUARD... THREE GUARDS have been dumped into the truck lift - Rohan sends it DOWN, SEALS the plane door. Mahir approaches the cockpit as the PILOTS perform checks - SHOWS THEM HIS GUN

dialogues.speaker: MAHIR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, lads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Staff Member leads Neil and the Protagonist into the vaults...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At gunpoint, the Pilots nervously pull back from the hang Rohan checks the stacks of GOLD BARS secured in the rear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane is TOWED back onto the taxiway and lifts its engines, easing forward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rohan SLASHES the restraining straps - CROUCHES behind th pile of gold - pulls out a GRENADE - GRABS the nearest go bar and STUFFS it into his waistband before PULLING THE PIN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Staff Member shows Neil and the Protagonist into a va Neil puts down his briefcase - pulls out the framed documents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The transport plane BARRELS down the taxiway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rohan TOSSES the grenade behind the gold at the tail of t plane and DUCKS as it BLOWS -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLASTING a hole in the rear of the plane... GOLD BARS POU OUT, CLATTERING ACROSS THE TARMAC...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hearing the distant explosion, the Protagonist and Neil s PACKING AIR... the Staff Member stares at them, quizzical

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (between breaths) Yoga.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahir forces the Pilots from their seats -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INFLATABLE SLIDE BURSTS OPEN, DRAGGING on the asphalt the Pilots roll onto it, SCRAMBLING DOWN to the ground, ROLLING AWAY from the giant plane...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahir TURNS the stick HARD LEFT, AIMING AT THE REAR WALL THE FREEPORT -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rohan lowers a ladder behind the forward landing gear - h and Mahir climb down -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mahir and Rohan jump down onto the asphalt, racing back between the wheels as the giant plane SMASHES INTO THE BR WALL OF THE FREEPORT, ERUPTING IN A MASSIVE EXPLOSION...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The vault is ROCKED by the explosion - ALARMS SCREAM - DO START CLOSING - Neil looks, panicked, at the Staff Member  45.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Ten seconds, right?! The Staff Member BOLTS - PUSHING PAST THEM - they take a gulp of air - GAS HISSES IN. They pull apart the frames o the documents, BREAKING THEM INTO LOCK-PICKING APPARATUS lockpicks, small crowbar - they go to work on the INNER D PRYING open a panel - HOT-WIRING it - the door SLIDES UP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They BURST into the corridor, GASPING - the door SLAMS DO behind them - they HUSTLE down to the next vault door - g to work. The door opens, they GULP AIR, then RACE inside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - round the corner past RACKS, CRATES, some BROKEN - stop the next door, the Protagonist picks the lock - his PICK BREAKS - Neil BOLTS back to where they entered - the Protagonist STRUGGLES, pulling out pieces of the pick - N gets to the first door - NO HANDLE - the Protagonist uses a different tool - Neil SMASHES the door, full-blown PANIC - he looks to the end the vault where the ROLLER DOOR is BROKEN at the bottom, halide gas HISSING OUT - Neil races towards it - the Protagonist gets his door OPE Neil STUMBLES past - the Protagonist DRAGS him through th door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lie GASPING. Neil hears something, looks around -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (urgent whisper) There’s someone in here with us! The Protagonist is up, moving down the corridor... They arrive at two doors, side by side: the Rotas vault. each work on a door. Neil’s OPENS -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Need a hand? The Protagonist works his door... nothing.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Actually, yes. Neil leans over, hits ‘ENTER’, the door OPENS.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist enters a room, one side of which is a LON GLASS WINDOW. Neil is on the other side of the glass, in IDENTICAL ROOM. There are BULLET HOLES in the glass. At t end of each room is a tube, like a sealed in REVOLVING DO The Protagonist’s feet crunch BROKEN GLASS... Neil examines BULLET HOLES in the wall opposite the glass WISPS of SMOKE gather near the holes - Neil reaches up -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Don’t touch them -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: What the hell happened here? The Protagonist sees a STRIPPED AUTOMATIC PISTOL on the floor. He picks it up, thinking -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: It hasn’t happened, yet. Neil looks at the Protagonist, quizzical - A LOUD HUM STA UP from the revolving door... the Protagonist looks down MOVEMENT beneath his feet - the DEBRIS - SMOKE GATHERS - revolving doors ROTATE, OPENING - a BLACK-CLAD FIGURE in GAS MASK LEAPS BACKWARDS from the tube - reaching behind itself to GRAB the stripped automatic in the Protagonist’ hand - On Neil’s side an identical BLACK-CLAD FIGURE LEAPS out FORWARDS - knocks Neil over, moving for the vault door - A SLIDE jumps into the Backwards Figure’s hand - he REASSEMBLES the gun in the Protagonist’s hand - a MAGAZIN jumping up to LOAD IT - BLAM! A bullet is SUCKED OUT OF THE WALL - THROUGH THE GLASS - ‘HEALING’ THE BULLET HOLES - the Protagonist STRUGGLES wi the Backwards Figure - whose REVERSE MOVEMENTS seem ALIEN IMPOSSIBLE -— Neil gives chase - RACING out of the vault door - The Backwards Figure pulls the Protagonist sideways, lini up his head with the next bullet hole - BLAM! GLASS FLIES as the shot JUST MISSES the Protagonist’s head -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil CHASES the Forwards Figure down the corridor -  47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist STRUGGLES - the Backwards Figure PUSHES h towards the next bullet hole, STRANGE REVERSE GROANING building in its throat, behind the black gas mask, the GR PEAKING AS the Protagonist takes his PICK and STABS the Backwards Figure in the arm and SMACKS the Figure’s gun o of its hand - it BOUNCES out the door - The Figure RISES into the Protagonist’s arms - PULLS him backwards - we can’t tell if it’s PUSHING or the Protagon is PULLING as they move backwards through the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Figure PUSHES/PULLS the Protagonist down the corridor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil RACES around a corner, GRABS the Figure’s MASK, whic COMES OFF - he looks, SURPRISED, at the Figure’s face, WH WE CANNOT SEE, then TURNS, RACING back the way he came...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist and the Backwards Figure struggle into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They SMASH into the racks and crates - the Protagonist GR the gun - raises it to the Figure’s head -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: NO! Don’t kill him! The Protagonist freezes - Neil steps up, DESPERATE —

dialogues.speaker: NEIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We need to know if you’re compromised. The Protagonist THROWS the Figure to the ground -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Why are you here?! The Protagonist tries to rip off the gas mask, but it is strapped tight - the REVERSE KEENING gets LOUDER and LOUD The Protagonist STEPS onto the Figure’s injured arm...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who sent you?!  48. The Figure’s reverse screaming gets louder - the Protagon KICKS its arm, HARD, AGAIN AND AGAIN -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: HOW DID YOU KNOW WE’D BE HERE! A BOOM! from outside - AIR starts BLOWING ACROSS the Backwards Figure, SUCKING underneath the broken roller do the Backwards Figure SLIDES impossibly across the floor a underneath the door which SLAMS shut, unbroken behind him The Protagonist and Neil look at each other...

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: We have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the plane’s JET ENGINES has come loose, STILL THRUSTING, SWINGING AROUND, wreaking HAVOC for the EMERGE SERVICES - an AMBULANCE SKIDS SIDEWAYS, avoiding the THRUST... Mahir and Rohan stand at a distance, watching the MAYHEM along with DOZENS of other UNIFORMED AIRPORT WORKERS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EMTS race in past the Staff Member...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil moves to the other door - works the lock - SIRENS so

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: What happened to the other guy?

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I took care of him. The door opens - they slip into the outer vault -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reassemble the document frames, then LIE DOWN, ‘unconscious’ - EMERGENCY SERVICES BURSTS IN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neil hangs up his phone -

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Mahir and Rohan slipped out clean. (turns to the Protagonist) I’ve seen too much and I’m still alive. Which means you’ve decided to trust me.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Or I’ve lost my edge.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Oh, your edge is intact. The Protagonist looks at Neil.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: There’s a cold war.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Nuclear?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Temporal.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Time travel?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: No. Technology that can invert an object’s entropy.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You mean reverse chronology. Like Feynman and Wheeler’s notion that a positron is an electron moving backwards in time.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Sure, that’s exactly what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: I’ve a master’s in physics.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Well, try to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: The implications of this are -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Beyond secret.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Then why’d you take me in?  50.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I thought we'd find the drawing and a couple boxes of bullets.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: You were as surprised as I was.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m going back to Mumbai for answers. I’1ll set you up as go- between. But remember - to you, all this is about plutonium. Or when we're done, they’1l kill you.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: Won’t you have to anyway?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I'd rather it was my decision.

dialogues.speaker: NEIL
dialogues.text: So would I. I think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist boards, approaching Priya at the rail.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: I don’t like to leave my house.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And I don’t like bungee jumping. But we need to talk.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: What about?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Inversion.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We spoke about it -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I don’t remember anything about people being inverted -

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We're trying to do with inversion what we couldn’t do with the atomic bomb - uninvent it. Divide and contain the knowledge. Ignorance is our ammunition - the more any one of us knows, the greater the risk that we’re actually making the situation worse.  51.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Risk more. Priya gestures at the paper. A headline: ‘OSLO GOLD FREIG CRASH - TERRORISM? ROBBERY? BOTH?’

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Your work? The Protagonist nods.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What did you find in the vaults?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Two antagonists, one inverted. We took out the regular one, the inverted one got away.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Both emerged at the same moment?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: They were the same person. You saw someone re-inverting. Sator’s built a turnstile in that vault.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Turnstile?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: A machine for inverting.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You told me the technology hasn’t been invented, yet.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: It hasn’t. He’s been given it by the future.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: You've the best chance of finding out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk, BODYGUARDS at a discreet distance.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Have you met him?  52.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I was close.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Get closer.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’ve been compromised. Unless that antagonist was a coincidence.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: The wife set you up?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Maybe. There’s a good chance I get killed as soon as I go back in.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: This was always a suicide mission - that’s why they recruited a corpse.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Who did? Who are we working for?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Everyone. Survival. You need more, consider yourself working for me.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Well, Boss, I need a way to succeed. Priya thinks. Looks at the Protagonist. Deciding.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: What if you have something he needs?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Such as?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Plutonium 241. Sator tried to lift the only loose 241 from under a CIA team at the opera siege in Kiev. He got the team, but not the 241.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Ukrainian security services. It’s moving through Tallinn in a week.  53.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Helping an arms dealer steal weapons-grade plutonium is unacceptable. I’m just gonna take him out.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: No. Sator has to stay alive until we know his part in things. Leverage the situation without losing control of the 241.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: It’s too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: A terrorist bomb, even one that kills millions, is nothing compared with what happens if we don’t stop Sator.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: From. Doing. What? Priya looks up the road at the cars STREAMING past...

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We're being attacked. Not by terrorists or rogue states...

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Who, then?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: We're being attacked by the future. And we're fighting over time.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Time?

dialogues.speaker: PRIYA
dialogues.text: Theirs is running out, so they’re coming for ours. And Sator is helping. You have to find out how.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Protagonist leaves the tourists behind, heading down leafy path to emerge at a terrace overlooking the sea. Ka stands there, alone. The Protagonist falls in beside her.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: I saw the news from Oslo. Do you have the drawing?  54.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: You don’t have to worry about it any more.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: You destroyed it?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you’d want it back.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Does he know?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Not yet, so sit tight.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Sit tight? Why? Every day my son spends with that monster, he thinks a little less of me.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: It won’t be long. In the meantime, introduce me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: As what?

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: I’m a former First Secretary from the American Embassy in Riyadh, we met at a party last June -

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: We were at a party in Riyadh, but I don’t think it was June -

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: June 29th. 7 for 7:30, salmon on the printed menu swapped for sea bass on the night. Sator left early, that’s when we met. Don’t offer any of this, it’s there if he asks. I came into Shipley’s in London, you ran into me here and want to show me the yacht.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: He’1l think we’re having an affair.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: And he’1l want to meet me.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
dialogues.text: Or have you killed.

dialogues.speaker: PROTAGONIST
dialogues.text: Let me worry about that.  55.

dialogues.speaker: KAT
